intro: Pentarrhinum coriaceum, commonly known as the rough-leaved pentarrhinum, is a species of flowering plant native to parts of South America. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its thick, leathery leaves and showy, five-petaled flowers that range in color from white to pink. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, often growing in moist, well-drained soils. Due to its ornamental value, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and greenhouses.
